div.l: O raise those eyes to me again
And smile again so joyously,
And fear not love, it was not pain
Nor grief that drew these tears from (me;
Beloved child thou canst not tell,
The thoughts that in my bosome swell
When e're I look on thee!
Thou knowest not that a glance (of thine,
Can bring back long departed years
And that thy blue eyes magic shine
Can overflow my own with tears,
And that each feature soft and fair
And every curl of golden hair,
Some sweet remembrance bears.
Just then thou didst recall to me
A distant long forgotten scene:
One smile and one sweet word from (thee
Dispelled the years that rolled between,
I was a little child again,
And every after joy and pain,
Seemed never to have been.
Tall forest trees waved over me,
To hide me from the heat of day,
And by my side a child like thee,
Among the summer flowerets lay.
He was thy sire thou merry child.
Like thee he spoke, like thee he (smiled,
Like thee he used to play,
O Mary Brontë changes the name here those were calm and happy days,
We loved each other fondly then
But human love too soon decays,
And ours can never bloom again.
I never thought to see the day
When his love and Florian's friendship would decay,Name added here at the expense of 'love'
Like that of colder men.
Now Mary Flora thou hast but begun
To sail on life's deceitful sea,
O do not err as I have done,
For I have trusted foolishly,
The faith of every friend I loved,
I never doubted till I proved
Their hearts inconstancy.
'Tis mournful to look back upon
Those long departed joys and cares,
And I will weep since thou alone
Art witness to my streaming tears,
This lingering love will not depart,
I can not bannish from my heart,
The friend of childish years,
But though thy Father loves me not,
Yet I shall still be loved by thee,
And though I am by him forgot,
Say wilt not thou remember me!
I will not cause thy heart to ache,
And for thy regretted Father's sake,
I'll love and cherrish thee.

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: “Verses to a Child,” which is dated 10 July 1838 but was not published during Brontë’s lifetime, is an early Gondal poem exploring themes of family, regret and nostalgia. The poem has the ‘signature’ of Alexandria Zenobia, a prominent character within the Gondal universe. In the amendments to the manuscript , which is now held at the Morgan Library and Museum, Brontë changes the child's name from 'Mary' to the pastoral 'Flora' and the unnamed father is christened 'Florian'. With these changes Brontë is affirming Flora's symbolic association with nature and innocence. Moreover, this strengthens the narrative association between father and daughter within the poem.

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: “A Fragment” written in 1840 as a Gondal poem and the manuscript is now held at the New York Public Library. It was later published by Brontë in the 1846 Poems by Currer, Ellis, and Acton Bell under the name 'Self-Congratulation' , creating a layer of ironic distance to the speaker’s declaration of her newfound maturity and emotional control. In the 1846 version, Brontë consistently removes more old-fashioned language which associates it with Gondal to create a more neutral affect. For example, 'thy' and 'wo' become the more modern 'your' and ‘woe' and the fantasy elements such as the signature of Olivia Vernon are removed.

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: “The Bluebell” is an 1840 poem explores themes of nature, nostalgia and was not published during Brontë's lifetime; the manuscript is now held at the Morgan Library and Museum. Brontë is honing her critical eye within her manuscript edits, for example experimenting with revisions in lines 42-43, where she ultimately opts for the aesthetically satisfying internal rhymes of 'heartless' and 'thankless'. Brontë also changes 'Bluebell' to 'lone flower' which enhances the personification and Romantic potency of the flower within the poem.

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: "An Orphan's Lament" is an unpublished Gondal poem written by Brontë in 1841, now held at the Morgan Library and Museum. This poem uses the imaginative potential of the Gondal genre as a springboard to delve into the topic of grief and provides a staunch defence of the emotional depth and capacity of children. The fair copy manuscript is largely intact with minor changes and bears the Gondal signature of A.H. above Brontë’s own.

div.l: That summer sun whose genial glow,

I long so much to see.

So gently cools my fevered brow,
This too Alas! must turn —
To a wild blast whose icy dart,
Pierces and chills me to the heart
Before I cease to mourn.
And these bright flowers I love so well,
VebinaSic Verbena - Rose and sweet bluebell

Those thick green leaves with all their shade
And rustling musick they must (fade
And every one decay.
But if the sunny Summer time

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: "Lines Written at Thorp Green" is a short 1841 poem not published by Brontë (and not to be confused with an 1840 poem which originally shared the name before being retitled to "Appeal" by Brontë in 1846) and is held at the Morgan Library and Museum. This poem shows a speaker's instinctive enjoyment of natural beauty being overtaken by the desire to be among family, linking nature, memory and nostalgia. The slightly unconventional capitalisations of the flower names 'Verbina' [sic] and 'Rose' enhance their importance to the speaker and the overall message of the poem.

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: "’Tis Strange to Think" was written in 1843, with the manuscript now held at the Morgan Library and Museum, and later renamed "Past Days" in the 1846 publication. The new name is apt as the poem comprises a speaker's reminiscence, combining nature, companionship and family to represent contentment. The 1846 version reverses the manuscript capitalisations of ‘Summer’, ‘Solitude' and 'Silence' to create a more standard text. Nonetheless, the 1846 text is keen to add emphasis to the opening and ending of the poem, with the words ‘was', 'reluctant' and 'labour' being fully capitalised.

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: “Memory” was written in 1844 and published in Poems by Currer, Ellis and Acton Bell in 1846. The manuscript was lost to public access for decades before being recently added to the Brontë Parsonage Museum collection in Haworth. This poem questions the role and scope of nostalgia when it comes to childhood and memory. This is underlined by the editorial changes made for the 1846 version, such as Brontë's capitalisation of 'Memory' and the capitalisation of 'ALL' in the phrase 'not ALL divine'. Additionally, swapping 'pure delight' to 'strange delight' shows Brontë recalibrating her poetry's alignment with Romantic language and actively undermining the imagined 'purity' of the delights of nature in favour of more sceptical language.

div.l: While on my lonely couch I lie
I seldome feel myself alone
For fancy fills my dreaming eye
With scenes and pleasures of its own
Then I may cherish at my breast
An infant's form beloved and fair
May smile and soothe it into rest
With all a mother's fondest care
How sweet to feel its helpless frorm
Depending thas thus on me alone
And while I hold it safe and warm
What bliss to think it is my own.
And glances then may meet my eyes,
That daylight never showed to me,
What raptures in my bosome rise,
Those earnest looks of love to see.
To feel my hand so kindly prest;
To know myself beloved at last,
To think my heart has found a rest -
My life of solitude is past.
But then to wake and find it flown
The dream of happiness destroyed,
To find myself unloved, alone,
What tongue can speak the dreary void?
A heart whence warm affections flow,
Creator thou hast given to me,
And am I only thus to know,
How sweet the joys of love would be?

div.head: Editor's note
div.p: “Dreams” is an 1845 poem that was recently added to the Brontë Parsonage Museum collection in Haworth. In this unpublished poem Brontë explores the possibilities and hazards of the classic Wordsworthian imaginative flight of fancy in a domestic context. The speaker turns to a Romanticised daydream of motherhood as an escape from loneliness which is only further magnified by her despairing return to reality. The final stanza features an X-shaped overstrike in pencil, indicating hesitancy on Brontë's part as to whether or not to include this stanza. Brontë is usually emphatic and unambiguous when marking sections for deletion within her manuscripts, so this mark underscores the authorial uncertainty about whether or not to leave the poem on an unresolved questioning of divine wisdom.

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: “Views of Life” was an extended project which was started in Spring 1844 and finished in June 1845. The manuscript is split between the Berg Collection at the New York Public Library and the Pierpoint Morgan Museum. In the manuscript the poem is untitled and 166 lines long and it was later published as “Views of Life” at 170 lines in the 1846 Poems. The poem traces a dialogue between Youth and Experience, in which the jaded pessimism of Experience is presented in extended detail before Youth’s invocation of Hope ultimately triumphs in the final verses. The seventh stanza has been rewritten with two line options for each of the lines 25-27 in the manuscript. However, Brontë’s line selection in the 1846 publication indicates her final decision, opting for the versions of the lines which prefers ‘dull clouds’ to ‘grey clouds’ and ‘borrowed charm’ to ‘transient glory’. Moreover, Brontë introduces internal repetition by following up with the line ‘The sky grew dull and charmless too’ as line 27. These changes combine to reduce the appeal of this image of nature, emphasising the cynicism of Experience in this moment.

And I must take a rougher part:
I seized him in my boistrous mirth;
As I sto bore him struggling to the earth,
And grappling, strength for strength we strove, —
He half in wrath,- I all for love;
But I gave o'er the strife at length,
Ashamed of my superior strength,-
The rather that I marked his eye
Kindle as if a change were nigh.
We paused to breath a little space,
Reclining on the heather brae;
But still I gazed upon his face
To watch the shadows pass away.
I grasped his hand, and it washad fled;-
A smile - a laugh - and all was well
Upon my breast he bent his head
And into graver talk we fell, —
More serious - yet so blest did seem
That calm communion quiet conference then,
That, when I found it but a dream,
I longed to sleep again.
At first, remembrance slowly woke,
Surprise — regret successive rose,

And dearest friends turn deadliest foes.
Then, like a cold, o'erwhelming flood
Upon my soul it burst —
This heart had thirsted for his blood;
This hand had allayed that thirst!
These eyes had watched, without a tear,
His dying agony;
These ears, unmoved, had heard his prayer;
This tongue had cursed him suff suffring there,
And mocked him bitterly!
Unwanted weakness o'er me crept;
I sighed — nay, weaker still — I wept!
Wept, like a woman o'er the deed
I had been proud to do;-
As I had made his bosom bleed;
My own was bleeding too.
Back foolish tears!- the man I slew
Was not the boy I cherished so;
And that young arm that clasped the friend
Was not the same that stabbed the foe:
By time and adverse thoughts estranged,
And wrongs and vengence, both were changed.
Repentence, now, were worse than vain:
Time's current cannot backward run;
And, be the action wrong or right,
It is for ever done.
Then reap the fruits - I've said his death
Should be his my country's gain:-
If not - then, I have spent my breath,
And split his blood in vain:
And I have laboured hard and long,
But little good attained;
My foes are many, yet, and strong,
Not half the battle's gained;
For, still, the greater deeds I've done,
The more are yetI have to do,
The faster I can journey on,
The farther I must go.
If Fortune favoured for a while,
I could not rest beneath her smile,
Nor triumph in success:
When I have gained one river's (shore
A wilder torrent stretched before,
Defies me with its deafening roar;
And onward I must press.
And, much I doubt, this work of strife,
In blood and death begun,
Will call for many a victim more
Before the cause is won.-
Well! my own life, I'd freely give
E Ere I would fail in my design;-
The cause must prosper if I live,
And I will die if it decline:
Advanced thus far, I'll not recede;-
Whether to vanquish or to bleed,
Onward, unchecked, I must proceed.
Be Death, or Victory mine!

div.head: Editor's Note
div.p: Written in 1846, "Z-'s Dream" is one of Brontë's final Gondal poems and is held at the Brontë Parsonage Museum. The title has been partly erased, making the original Gondal name illegible and the ending bears the Gondal signature “C. L.”. Within the poem Brontë uses a dream sequence to explore male relationships. From this springboard Brontë interrogates ideas around gender and violence as well as themes of regret via the invocation of the lost innocence of youth. Within the manuscript, Brontë reconfigures one section quite drastically. The new lines show Brontë emphasising the young friend's external and internal connection to nature. Depiction of the weather and environment is mediated via its interactions with the child while he is shown appreciating these elements.
